awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Investigation of Nucleation Dynamics on Nanoengineered Surfaces for Durable and High Heat Flux Condensation Phase Change Applications
awd_abstract_narration:
The project entails the fundamental study of condensation phase change on nanoengineered surfaces, covered with an ultrathin hydrophobic or super-hydrophobic coating. A significant outcome of the project is the possibility of engineering or "designing" better (more resilient) surfaces. The study has potential to impact several industries, such as power utilities, heating ventilation and air-conditioning equipment, electronic devices, and desalination systems.
 
The main objective is to determine the surface coating defects formation, degradation and nucleation dynamics during condensation, which is key to enhancing longevity and heat transfer effectiveness of the surface. A new advanced scanning probe microscopy technique will be utilized for process visualization. Educational effort is very broad, involving research experience activities for k-12 teachers and students, new laboratory activities for undergraduate engineering students, and a new graduate course.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

por.por_cntn:
The outcome of this CAREER proposal was the development of comprehensive understanding of defect formation, degradation, and nucleation dynamics on nanoengineered surfaces during condensation phase change. Classically, ultra-thin hydrophobic coatings have been studied for more than 80 years for dropwise condensation heat transfer enhancement due to their potential for 10X heat transfer enhancement when compared to currently utilized filmwise condensation. More recently, nanoengineered surfaces enabling coalescence induced droplet jumping at length scales approaching 10 ?m, have been developed with 30% higher heat transfer than state-of-the-art dropwise condensation. However, implementation of these novel surfaces is difficult due to a lack of knowledge of the defect formation and degradation mechanisms, which are inexorably linked to the nucleation dynamics on the surface and hold the key to enhancing both longevity and heat transfer. Outcomes of this project include the development of a detailed mechanistic understanding of defect formation and nucleation dynamics on smooth hydrophobic and nanoengineered superhydrophobic surfaces. The degradation mechanisms have enabled us to develop coatings for numerous transformative applications, such as enhanced efficiency power plants and HVAC systems, higher power and more reliable electronic devices, and efficient thermal seawater desalination.

The project utilized methods based on advanced scanning probe microscopy techniques to observe for the first time the dynamic formation of defect and nucleation sites. The changes in the distribution of defect sites and their shapes as condensation phase change, chemical oxidation, droplet impact, and thermal degradation were systematically applied to the nanoengineered coatings to reveal how the degradation mechanisms affect specific defect formation modes and nucleation on these defects during condensation. This enabled us to develop fundamental understanding of the degradation mechanisms underpinning the lack of robustness of nanoengineered surfaces, and allow the rational design of surfaces for high heat flux applications. 

Given the importance of phase change thermal transport processes on modern technology, the project outcomes developed here have broad impact on numerous applications such as power generation, desalination, building environmental control, and electronics thermal management. The realization of next-generation technologies to enhance phase change heat transfer is of critical importance due to its impact on the approaching energy and water crises. The broader impacts of the integrated research and education plan are a (1) transformative understanding of the role of nanoengineered surfaces on fundamental heat transfer mechanisms, (2) disruptive technological advancements in phase change heat transfer systems, and (3) the integration of nanoscience and mechanical engineering at all levels of education from K-12 through graduate school, with a focus on relevant global challenges. The integrated educational objectives of this proposal have fostered interest in science for students of all ages and engage students in research activities.


Last Modified: 04/02/2022
Modified by: Nenad Miljkovic
